monogr.title: Drum Beats: Walt Whitman's Civil War Boy Lovers

bibl.author: William E. Vandemark
bibl.title: William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman, 29 December 1863
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library

body.p: to day iI received a letter from yoyou and iI was glad to here from yoyou iI am not very well and have not benbeen for some time iI have pain in my head and breast iI think the clorformchloroform that iI have taken is the causcause of it my hip is very painful to day iI was exasamendexamined iI think that iI will go before the board in a day or two iI may get my discharge iI have hurdheard that my ridgementregiment is going home for the winter to recruit thairthere is only 17 men left innyany more for duty father iI long to see yoyou and have a talk with yoyou iI will try and get a pas to go to Washington to see yoyou after iI have benbeen before the board for another exsamanationexamination

father iI hope yoyou had a good time a CrismisChristmas & iI hope yoyou en Joyed yiouryour Self watwhat a blessed privelgeprivilege it is to be so that we can en Joy the privelageprivilege wile some are on beds of sickness and have benbeen cut off in their youth—

dear father iI wish yoyou a happy new yrs and a good time iI will try and get a pas to come and see yoyou next fridayFriday iI hantehaven't sure of getting one yet but iI will try to get one—iI like this place very well here iI will never go to new york aginagain on a trans bus for they use men thairthere worse than dogs iI would have done better if iI had staid in washingtonWashington they know how to use men thairthere and how to taktake caircare of them wen iI see yoyou iI will teltell yoyou all

I think the war is nearly ended now I hope it is at all events, for thairthere has been men enufenough lost on both sides in one war how many widows and orphans it has caused all ready—iI wish that iI could get detailed in washingtonWashington at some thing that iI coudcould do iI woudwould be very glad and would try to do my duty—father let me Know how things gets a long in army squairsquare teltell crain that hantehaven't had answer from the letter that iI sent him and iI would like to here from him iI have seen hathford wen iI was home and had a talk with him he is all rite now
father iI will close good by dear father and friend from a friend William E Vandermark to a dear friend Walt Whitman good by
